content:
It just occurred to me as I'm updating issues and suggesting new projects that I'm doing so in the middle of a global health crisis.

In fact, I'm probably working on Backdrop tonight in part to distract myself from that fact. I want to acknowledge that things in the world are pretty crazy and we all react to it differently. After a day or two of being pretty stressed, I'm diving into work to keep myself busy. Not everyone may be able to do that right now.

If your situation is different right now, I get that. I hope that we're all doing what we need to do to take care of ourselves and our families. That might involve working in the issue queue, it might mean taking time away from Backdrop and focusing on your physical and mental health and safety.

I just hope that everyone is doing what they need to do, to stay healthy and sane.

For someone who purposefully tries to stay away from news and social media (because its 95% bad, depressing news, even without a global health crisis), I'm finding it increasingly difficult to ignore the announcements, updates, etc.

On top of all that, my family has flights from Estonia to Australia booked on the 25th of March as we're moving back home. But as airport after airport shuts down I feel the noose tightening...

Well, I hesitate to bring it up. Because, I know we are all hearing more about it than we would like already and may see Backdrop CMS as an escape. But, I think it's at least important to acknowledge that this is happening and may be effecting some of us harder than others.

Personally, I am taking this very seriously, but at the same time with a "zen" mindset, that certain things are simply beyond our control. We can only do the responsible/ethical thing as human beings, and limit in-person social interactions to a minimum. ...having said that though, I just had a discussion with my wife over hangouts (she has to deal with a 9yo + 3 heavily depended on us 80yo's - which are in the high-risk group) ...I know that I should not let my emotions/family get in the way, and instead do the responsible/ethical thing as a human being, which is to cancel my flight to Greece on April 3. ...I am weak though, and seriously considering moving my planned flight to ASAP instead (like this week)
...now back to what @StPaulTim was saying: I am a self-diagnosed chronically depressed person (I don't think I can get more depressed than that :sweat_smile:), and also ataraxic; so the crisis does not effect me like it does most people. So my reactions are more like prepare-for-the-worse rather than panic-and-start-stockpiling. I've mentioned in the past that over many years I have found contributing to Backdrop, and interacting with all of you guys to be truly therapeutic! ...knowing that you are part of something bigger, which has the nobble purpose to help others, really does help in hard times.
I love you all ...take care and stay safe :heart:

I'm just starting to change some habits to have more social distancing. It seems that many of us already work from home so that part is covered. My family and I just moved to a small city from Toronto so that probably helped. But sooner or later the virus will reach here.

Even though I'm healthy and low risk for getting seriously ill from it. I want to limit the spread to others, especially elderly relatives. We can take some pressure off local hospitals by trying to slow down the spread
In fact, that's the language Toronto's public health used: slow the spread

I wouldnt advise anyone travel anywhere for the foreseeable future TBH. One because its the responsible thing to do, and also because it could be really inconvenient for you and family if someone on your plane/boat becomes a suspect; you would end up stuck somewhere for 15 days against your will, away from your family.
I've just spent all of Friday being the throat swab person on our team (we rotate). Theyve locked down our country: no ships, screening everyone at airports, no one allowed from Europe, USA, most of the world, no public gatherings, no church, no schools. Its not fun.
Take this seriously, even if your country still allows it stay home, dont visit, dont travel, wait this out.
Also if anyone has medical questions, I'd be happy to answer them.
I'm starting to understand why @docwilmot's username starts with 'doc'...
:smiley:
its an open secret: https://backdropcms.org/account/docwilmot
Aha!
Brother klonos I think you are brilliant and I greatly admire the use you make of your talents. Thank you. And thanks to all of the Backrop team.
Some jokes to make this easier: https://www.drupal.org/project/commerce_toiletpaper
^^ one of the guys working on GovCMS has created this module. It allows to use toilet paper as currency, to pay in Drupal Commerce sites :laughing:
(context: it's been a few weeks that people have emptied the supermarkets in Australia from TP - it's become hard to find)
So the police that are forcing the quarantine in Italy are called the "Carabinieri" ...what are the rest of the Italians called?
...Quarantinieri!! :laughter_tears:
(it's not funny though ...but it is)
...oh, come on @StPaulTim ...in times like these we need to keep the spirit up :slight_smile:
...and this one is actually true:
tp-checked-luggage-SYD.png

I have gone to stay with my parents during this time of turmoil, in rural Minnesota. There is plenty of toilet paper here, but my mother spends much of her day on Facebook and apparently, the toilet paper jokes and memes are quite numerous (and many of them quite good).
It does help lighten the mood.

It does help indeed. And although sad, we need to keep in mind that there's no need to worry about things that are beyond our control. Until there is a cure/vaccine, there will unfortunately be casualties :disappointed:
...just take care, and try your best to stay safe.

A lot has been said about the the virus... Here in Switzerland, the infection rate has tripled(!)within the past 24 hours. A complete shutdown for malls, stores, restaurants is expected to be announced today.

But let me tell a tiny story about Backdrop CMS.

Saturday, I received a call from a restaurant customer. He quickly changed the concept for the weekend towards a takeaway service. I took my laptop, and we quickly setup a landing page, a newsletter and a social media post to inform people that the restaurant is open Sunday (= yesterday). The response was overwhelming, a lot of people sent congrats to the restaurant owner, for his good idea (the venue is pretty popular over the weekends, great view to the Alps).

And guess what? Backdrop really made a difference for me. Sure, Drupal 8 or any other CMS can also setup a text-only page within a few minutes. But I was able to change also the layout and a few other details very quickly, right at the restaurant table. The customer was pretty impressed (the old CMS was Contao, quite popular here, and quite complicated).

Today, I will continue to build my SMB platform on Backdrop, where config management plays an important role. There will be more customers which need a helping hand in the weeks to come, and Backdrop’s *flexibility” will be the base for the solution.

So @StPaulTim @BWPanda (Peter) @klonos, @docwilmot, @jenlampton @Nate Lampton and everyone that I forgot to mention... I just wanted so say that your work, your attention to details really counts, also during these times. All the best to you and your beloved ones.

The library is closed. I’m still getting paid. I get work on the Backdrop site without any distractions at home. I can make a Backdrop version of my portfolio site and my orchestras website. Time to learn stuff too. It’s not all bad...yet.
Ah, so maybe the staff and librarians are not expendable. :slight_smile:
At least for us. Others are having a tough time.
Also we’ll find out how expendable we are in the budget crisis that’s soon to follow the immediate crisis.
Yep.
Hullo all; just want to say that I appreciate this conversation greatly; thanks y'all. Sending love, luck and strength out to everyone.

TP currency module! wooo.
I love this sort of gallows humor

The problem now is that the city is trying to apply the hurricane emergency policy to a pandemic because there is no policy for this. Working from home is a foreign concept. So you know, I'm probably going to do it anyway.

Stay safe everyone (especially @docwilmot !).

I'd say social distancing and being forced to stay home would mean more time to work on my Backdrop projects... but now the kids are here all day, too, and I'll be catching up on other work a lot in the evenings. :big_smile:

I've mentioned before that the Australian government has chosen the GovCMS distro/platform as the go-to solution for all gov agencies. So I have always been an advocate of the idea that Drupal should be a course in schools ...so teach the kids Backdrop @Laryn !!! :wink:
...we could use a young generation of Backdropers. Get them young and all :sweat_smile:
the SF bay area is now under a "Shelter in place" order, so perhaps more time for backdrop :)
yikes!
Now see there's a term I'm familiar with. If we told all the Floridians to shelter in place and this was just a huge hurricane eye they might stay inside.
#flattenthecurve

I'm curious how other locations are phrasing things. Here they are talking about "slowing down the spread". I think they're saying the virus will hit many people in our community but the longer we can delay the more hospitals can handle the serious cases
Same here @Herb
image.png keep the kitty lazy
Here in UK we, as over 70 year olds, are 'self isolating' and this will become a government requirement very soon. But not enforced by police.

This is the map I was using to get a general idea of what's been happening worldwide: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/coronavirus-maps.html

Coronavirus Map: Tracking the Global Outbreak
The virus has infected more than 227,900 people in at least 148 countries.
...they've updated it today, to reflect countries where the daily reported cases is decreasing (China for example, that was previously on the red now is not)

And this map is the less "frustrating" one, as it also shows the number of people that have recovered: https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html

Johns Hopkins Coronavirus Resource Center
Johns Hopkins experts in global public health, infectious disease, and emergency preparedness have been at the forefront of the international response to COVID-19.

here's an interesting set of data visualizations and links to the data sources if you want to do your own analysis/visualizations https://www.tableau.com/covid-19-coronavirus-data-resources

COVID-19 (Coronavirus) Data Resource Hub
We are facing an unprecedented public health crisis with the Coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak. We believe that data-driven decisions, and people working together for the greater good, are the best way through this difficult time. Right now, it's more important than ever to have the resources to answer critical questions that matter to your organization and people. This includes having access to timely, detailed, and trustworthy data to think quickly and move fast. We have gathered the power of our Tableau Community and our technology to create a free Covid19 Data Resource Hub to help you make confident decisions with data.

Just wanted to share this in case people have the capacity/energy/motivation to help education go on in times like these: https://education-nation.99math.com/

Here's a list of remote learning solutions from Estonia you can use right now for free
Estonia is a top education nation. Now education solutions offer their services for free and support via daily webinars.

...landed in Athens at 12pm. The cab driver was at the airport since 2am waiting for a ride. The city almost empty. ...now have to wait 3hrs for the bus to my hometown (reduced schedules), but at least I'm "home". Getting there :sweat_smile:

Finally home :tada: ...awkward feeling on the bus, as we passed by the village where my wife and daughter are at (knowing for a moment that they're 5min away, but I won't get to see them for another 2 weeks). ...then back at the apartment, my mom crying at a 2 meter distance, cause she can't hug me. ...oh well, the important thing is that I'm here. Just keep my brain busy, like I always do, and hopefully 14 days will fly by :slight_smile: ...stay safe all, and I'll catch you online soon. ...I feel like I'm gonna sleep for 2 days.
@klonos - so glad to hear that you made it. Good luck.
@klonos I know you've probably said this already, but how long are you there for?

The original ticket was for April 3 - return May 16. This one now is a one-way ticket ...I'll get back to Australia when it's safe ...and when they allow it (I'm a permanent resident now, so it's easier - but you never know how things will evolve with this situation) ...IOW, it's a wait-n-see at the moment.
That sounds like a better deal for you and your family. :slight_smile:
That's quite an ordeal @klonos. I'm glad you made it and hope the wait goes smoothly

For those with kids at home, my colleagues have found this site useful: https://www.khanacademy.org/

Khan Academy | Free Online Courses, Lessons & Practice
You can learn anything. Expert-created content and resources for every course and level. Always free.
(unfortunately, only in English - so my daughter can't use it)
All of my kids have all been homeschooled, so this situation is not novel for us. :slight_smile:
@klonos I'm thinking of you and hoping you are okay this week!
I'm doing fine @jenlampton :heart: ...a bit overwhelmed with work, but in a good way ...so no stress; just no time :sweat:

...my 14-day self-isolation is almost over by the way; the missus is coming to pick me up on Monday, and we'll go to the village. I'll get lots of hugs from her and my daughter, and the world will be a much better place once again :slight_smile:

BTW, I was thinking that we should introduce "Backdrop weekends" now that everyone is staying indoors with this whole COVID thing :wink: ...something like a live stream (like the watercooler chat others have mentioned) + working on Backdrop at the same time.
I thought about doing that today, but never really had a clear enough block of time.
That'll be the fun of it ...no need for a clear block of time ...everyone should just go about their day as per usual - just keep logged into a live stream if you feel like it.
...we can chat about Backdrop, or anything really.
...if people wanna work on a specific thing, they can agree on a private jitsi/hangout/zoom among themselves, and get things done :wink:

Talking about stupidity/dumbness... Sadly, we have incidents in my hometown with the Roma community :disappointed: ...they refuse to abide by the distancing regulations, and they have been gathering in the dozens/hundreds for weddings etc. ...they refuse to believe that there is a virus :face_palm: :rolling_eyes: ...gov is now considering deploying the army to enforce them to stay in quarantine https://www.thenationalherald.com/297162/greece-locks-down-roma-camp-after-coronavirus-found/

Greece Locks Down Roma Camp After Coronavirus Found
LARISSA, Greece – After quarantining two refugee and migrant camps, Greek health authorities locked down a Roma settlement in Larissa, central Greece after 18 people …

Quoting my best friend from back when we were teens:

I'm not afraid of one or two stupid people, but things change when they come in large groups.
I can see how the Roma are highly suspicious. In some places Covid seems to be an excuse for removing freedoms and reducing privacy

I agree; corruption is everywhere ...still not a valid excuse to be spreading the infection to others. It's their own people that got infected and are in risk to die now :shrug: ...perhaps that'll be enough to convince them.
